<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_chmod:
```c
int32 OS_chmod(const char *path, uint32 access_mode)
{
    char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileChmod_Impl(local_path, access_mode);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The array declaration itself does not call any <string.h> functions so it does not by itself violate Rule 21.17. A violation can occur if the translator/writer routine writes more bytes than OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN into local_path using string functions. For example, if OS_TranslatePath(local_path) does strcpy(local_path, path) or strcat/local_memcpy without bounds checking and strlen(path) >= OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN, then accesses beyond local_path[] bounds would occur and Rule 21.17 would be violated.
